key_insight: GITIII is a lightweight, self-supervised graph transformer that infers single-cell–level interactions by learning and interpreting correlations between a cell's state and its local niche, producing interpretable scores that quantify how neighbouring cells influence a receiver cell's gene expression.
problem_solved: Provides an interpretable, scalable method to infer and quantify spatial cell–cell interactions from spatial transcriptomics data, addressing the challenge of detecting who influences whom at single-cell resolution in complex tissues.
method: Build a spatial cell graph linking cells/locations by proximity and gene-expression features.
Train a self-supervised graph transformer to learn representations of cell states and niche correlations without explicit interaction labels.
Interpret model outputs (e.g., attention/correlation scores) to quantify neighbour-to-receiver influence on gene expression at single-cell resolution.
impact: Enables researchers and ML practitioners to extract biologically meaningful, interpretable interaction maps from spatial transcriptomics, improving downstream hypothesis generation, perturbation design, and integration of spatial context into predictive models.
visual_elements: Tissue image overlaid with a spatial cell graph (nodes = cells, edges = neighbourhood links)
Heatmap or spatial map of per-cell influence scores showing which neighbours drive expression changes
Schematic of the self-supervised graph-transformer pipeline (graph construction → transformer encoding → interpretation module)
Bar or violin plots comparing inferred interaction strengths across cell types or conditions
paper_title: Inferring spatial single-cell-level interactions through interpreting cell state and niche correlations learned by self-supervised graph transformer
paper_authors: Xiao Xiao, Le Zhang, Hongyu Zhao, Zuoheng Wang
